BY MARK TRACHTENBERG
The restrooms in the Milton
S. Eisenhower Library were
closed briefly for treatment with
pesticides last week, after two
librarians reported seeing lice on
the toilets in the staff ladies'
room on M-Level.
The staff members, Vikki
Bivens and Pinky Edgerton of
the Preparation Department,
said they first saw the lice on
Friday, February 8. Custodians
closed the bathroom immediately and sprayed. "The Building
Services people were very responsive," Bivens said.
But Bivens again, found
lice in the restroom the following
Tuesday, this time in a different
stall. The room was closed and
sprayed once more.
The custodial staff called in
a professional exterminator to
treat all the Library's restrooms
thoroughly,
according to
Ken Cain, Director of Building

Services for the Homewood
campus. "No lice were found
anywhere but that one ladies'
room," Cain said. "but we
decided to deal with all the
bathrooms as a precautionary
measure."
In order to. minimize inconvenience the Library's patrons,
only 'half the bathrooms were
sprayed at a time. Exterminators
treated restrooms on Q, A and C
Levels on Thursday night, and
those on M, B and D levels
Saturday night. All bathrooms
were closed for one day after
treatment.
Cain said the custodial
staff worked overtime on Sunday night in over to clean up
after the exterminators, since
they had to remove much of the
paneling in the bathrooms in
order to spread the powder. All
the restrooms were opened by
Monday.
No lice have been seen since
then, and no cases of human
irlfestation have been reported.

the Student Council will sponsor

according to Committee chairman Robert Elkin, is to "inform

(of education at Hopkins) and to
get input."
Some of the topics to be
considered are Intersession, the
quality of advising, combined
degree programs, independent
study and plus/minus grading.
.Broader problems, such as the
University's mission in undergraduate education, will also be
discussed.
The Committee plans to use
the information they receive
during the forums with data
compiled from surveys taken
earlier this year to present a
consensus of student opinion to
the Committee on Undergraduate Studies (CUS). The Academic Council has directed CUS to
review the report submitted by
the Curriculum Review Committee (CRC) at the end of last
December. CUS will hold several
meetings in March to examine
the CRC report before making
their recommendations to the
Academic Council.

the report as it now stands is
much narrower than it was
originally. Although the CRC
did deal with some specific
problems, such as course
requirements, advising and Intersession, it did not provide a
comprehensive _discussion of the
University's responsibility to its
students. The Education Committee hopes to raise student
consciousness and generate
interest in the quality of education at Hopkins by providing
forums for discussion, according
to Elkin.
"This is a university where
faculty autonomy and independence is maintained and
fought for very hard," said
Elkin. He believes therefore
that it is necessary for students
to be aware of and concerned
with the academic atmosphere
provided at JHU. "This is an

Who Needs Peabody?
The Peabody Conservatory is
broke. Again.
Unfortunately, the only response
this fact has elicited from most Hopkins
students has been a resounding "So
what?" Undergraduates here are notorious for having only the sketchiest knowledge of Baltimore, but unfamiliarity with
a valuable part of one's own university
which lies only twenty blocks away is not
easily excusable. The fact of the matter is
that if Peabody ceases to exist, the
absence will be sorely felt by all of
Hopkins, and we will have lost a rare asset
and fine opportunity.
We will not dwell on the great
intrinsic merits of supporting an institution the caliber of Peabody, because, for
one reason or another, such arguments
seem to have little persuasive power on
this campus. Instead, we will take a
purely selfish approach and ask "What can
Peabody do for Homewood?"
For one thing, it can help to
discredit the image Hopkins has as a
monolithic pre-med factory. Despite the
many strong Humanities departments
here, most outsiders still assume that
anyone attending Hopkins wants to be a
doctor. Having a world-famous conservatory connected to the University might go
far toward softening our distorted, hard—
science image.
It is a truism that Hopkins is a sec-

a

Hopkins seems to be the place where
undergrads who couldn't quite make it into
Princeton wind up. One of the factors
which make Ivy League schools so revered
is that they possess excellent institutions
which are distinct from their basic Arts &
Sciences curriculum:
Harvard Law,
Yale Divinity, etc. In Peabody, Hopkins
has just such an "Ivy League" asset. A
top-notch conservatory, in conjunction
with the existing top-notch School of
Medicine, can put to rest many of the
excuses employed to keep Hopkins
out of the first eschelon of American
universities.

Come Clean, Cates
BY LINDSAY KAPLAN
Each week the News-Letter
offers its readers the chance to
express their opinions in the
form of letters to the Editor. At
the beginning of this semester,
the editorial staff of the N-L was
given a similar privilege with
the reinstatement of a column
called "Opinion." Each week an
editor or a staff member is
responsible on a rotating basis
for filling this space with his or
her opinion. The column is
signed, which indicates to the
reader that the author alone is
responsible for the article, and
that the opinions are solely his
(or her, in this case) own.
Now that the status of this
statement, as well as that of
lettters to the Editor, has
been established, let me ask a
question. Who wrote that article
directly above and to the right
of mine? A surprisingly large
amount of people think that the
article in question, commonly
referred to as an editorial, is the
opinion of the entire editorial

staff. Plausible hypothesis. But
let me ask another question. If
the editorial expresses my
opinions, as well as those of my
colleagues, what need have we
for the space set aside for
"Opinion"?
A misconception obviously
exists here which I feel responsible to clear up. The editorial
does not express (as it did in the
past) the view of the entire
editorial staff; in fact it does not
express the views of part of the
editorial staff. To be frank, I
don't even know what the
editorial is going to be until I see
the paper Friday morning.
I am not trying to find fault
with the editorials written by
our Editor-In-Chief, Cates Baldridge; on the contrary, I believe
that they are for the most part
intelligent, well-written opinions. My complaint is that they
are his opinions, not mine, and

Graduation! The big day has finally arrived.
Your extended childhood is over, and you're ready to
assume a place in the "Real World." And because
you're a JHU grad, you expect to assume a significant
place. In other words, a degree from mighty Johns
Hopkins guarantees success.
This may be the way it works for some people,
but for other bonafide Hopkins men and women, Ringo
Starr's song says it all. This article, written as it is by
a '78 Hopkins grad, is designed to advise graduating
seniors concerning the months after graduation, which
can be a tough time for most people.
I hope the ideas and realities discussed here will
be reassuring, or at least informative, to those who
graduate and find that success does not fall into one's
lap. The Alumni Association will ask for dues, and the
person responsible for getting funds from your class will
try to milk money from you for the old alma mater, and
you'll get those forms to fill out which ask you what
your position is (dishwasher?), but no Hopkins official is
going to come down off his/her throne to tell you that
Hopkins grads are not "can't miss" overnite sensations.
Believe me, the Placement Office is only helpful if you
don't need its assistance in the first place. Besides, they
told you when you applied that you shouldn't come
here unless you knew what you wanted to do.
There are two groups of people for whom the
information presented here is not particularly relevant.
People who are (1) going directly on to grad school; and
(2) engineers and the like people who get great (17-20 K
per annum) jobs right away. Such folks will probably
not experience that great change of life crisis which
begins when one walks out of the hallowed halls of the
ivory tower with a BA or BS, a crisis known as Post-Graduate Depression.
Post-Graduate Depression is a malaise which is
almost never fatal, but it's damned uncomfortable while
it lasts -- and that may be a year or two. For most, it
can last at least a summer. PGD, as we might call it,
involves the dawning realization that one has been thrust
into a game with rules which differ from those of
college. The young man who lounges so cavalierly in
front of Levering with his tattered jeans and free-style
hair, puffing on a joint, will find that the admiration his
care-free actions generate on campus is not to be found
in the Real World. There is no more tragic sight than the
Big Man On Campus who one apring struts across his
turf like a sexual tycoon, while the next finds him
cowering in some executive's office with a fresh haircut,
groveling for a job.

Post-Graduate Depression is usually over when the
subject has adapted to the Real World, i.e. is self-supporting, and has adjusted his/her social life to the
working routine. The transformation is tough, because
the job market is crowded. And if you're a white male,
your shot at a good management track program is cut
by, say, 2/3, because those women who were once
content to be secretaries, and those minorities who once
never made it to college, want a slice of your action with a vengeance. That realization doesn't make your
ego feel any better when the days are long and lean.
Adjusting socially is as tough as getting the job.
First, you can't party until four in the morning and then
sleep through that ten o'clock class. Chronic absenteeism can blight your budding career pronto. Not only
that, but after you graduate, you find you can't hang
out in front of Levering, or in the Rat, Library, coffee
shop, or other former favorite haunts, without attracting
the goading question, "What are you doing here?" I
swear that I have encountered this question almost every
time I've been on campus since that September in '78
when I glumly closed my Gilman bank account(low on
funds) as the cheery underclassmen returned. The
question is irritating in any case, because it implies
(correctly) that you're no longer "one of us." And if
you have a lousy job or no job, you don't want to field
the inevitable questions about what you're doing with
your life, especially if those questions are tossed at you
by some bright-eyes undergrad who wields the whip
innocently but effectively. I mean, you already have
your dad telling you to "get a job" and asking "Why do
you think I spent a fortune putting you through
school?"
See what I mean? When you graduate, you have
a new social status and role as surely as a man in nineteenth century America who is suddenly transmogrified
from white to black. And the people who aren't standing in your shoes will not give a shit about your predicament. Those who haven't gotten this far don't know
what you're going through, and those who have already
passed this stage don't want much to do with anyone
who is going through "that stage." Those who have
successfully resisted the urge to become a leftist during
school sometimes succumb in the midst of Post-Graduate Depression. They thus suddenly stumble onto a
dandy new make-shift philosophy -"Hey, everybody
ought to have a job!" This usually lasts until capitalism
has mercy on them and gives them a place in the sun,at
which point they abandon their foolish ideas and completely forget about everyone back in the ringer.

I was one, there aren't a lot of alternatives. The fact
that one was, say, the smartest kid in one's High School

organizations don't want you unless you have skills

they don't have much demand for English majors.

treatment.

staff worked overtime on Sunday night in over to clean up
after the exterminators, since
they had to remove much of the
paneling in the bathrooms in
order to spread the powder. All
the restrooms were opened by
Monday.

then, and no cases of human
irlfestation have been reported.

Who Needs Peabody?
The Peabody Conservatory is
broke. Again.
Unfortunately, the only response
this fact has elicited from most Hopkins
students has been a resounding "So
what?" Undergraduates here are notorious for having only the sketchiest knowledge of Baltimore, but unfamiliarity with
a valuable part of one's own university
which lies only twenty blocks away is not
easily excusable. The fact of the matter is
that if Peabody ceases to exist, the
absence will be sorely felt by all of
Hopkins, and we will have lost a rare asset
and fine opportunity.
We will not dwell on the great
intrinsic merits of supporting an institution the caliber of Peabody, because, for
one reason or another, such arguments
seem to have little persuasive power on
this campus. Instead, we will take a
purely selfish approach and ask "What can
Peabody do for Homewood?"
For one thing, it can help to
discredit the image Hopkins has as a
monolithic pre-med factory. Despite the
many strong Humanities departments
here, most outsiders still assume that
anyone attending Hopkins wants to be a
doctor. Having a world-famous conservatory connected to the University might go
far toward softening our distorted, hard—
science image.
It is a truism that Hopkins is a sec-

a

ond-choice haven for Ivy League also-rans.
Hopkins seems to be the place where
undergrads who couldn't quite make it into
Princeton wind up. One of the factors
which make Ivy League schools so revered
is that they possess excellent institutions
which are distinct from their basic Arts &
Sciences curriculum:
Harvard Law,
Yale Divinity, etc. In Peabody, Hopkins
has just such an "Ivy League" asset. A
top-notch conservatory, in conjunction
with the existing top-notch School of
Medicine, can put to rest many of the
excuses employed to keep Hopkins
out of the first eschelon of American
universities.
Part of the reason for student
apathy is that the great resources of
Peabody are not being handled properly.
The concerts, most of them free, are not
well publicized at Homewood, and

Graduation! The big day has finally arrived.
Your extended childhood is over, and you're ready to
assume a place in the "Real World." And because
you're a JHU grad, you expect to assume a significant
place. In other words, a degree from mighty Johns
Hopkins guarantees success.
This may be the way it works for some people,
but for other bonafide Hopkins men and women, Ringo
Starr's song says it all. This article, written as it is by
a '78 Hopkins grad, is designed to advise graduating
seniors concerning the months after graduation, which
can be a tough time for most people.
I hope the ideas and realities discussed here will
be reassuring, or at least informative, to those who
graduate and find that success does not fall into one's
lap. The Alumni Association will ask for dues, and the
person responsible for getting funds from your class will
try to milk money from you for the old alma mater, and
you'll get those forms to fill out which ask you what
your position is (dishwasher?), but no Hopkins official is
going to come down off his/her throne to tell you that
Hopkins grads are not "can't miss" overnite sensations.
Believe me, the Placement Office is only helpful if you
don't need its assistance in the first place. Besides, they
told you when you applied that you shouldn't come
here unless you knew what you wanted to do.
There are two groups of people for whom the
information presented here is not particularly relevant.
People who are (1) going directly on to grad school; and
(2) engineers and the like people who get great (17-20 K
per annum) jobs right away. Such folks will probably
not experience that great change of life crisis which
begins when one walks out of the hallowed halls of the
ivory tower with a BA or BS, a crisis known as Post-Graduate Depression.
Post-Graduate Depression is a malaise which is
almost never fatal, but it's damned uncomfortable while
it lasts -- and that may be a year or two. For most, it
can last at least a summer. PGD, as we might call it,
involves the dawning realization that one has been thrust
into a game with rules which differ from those of
college. The young man who lounges so cavalierly in
front of Levering with his tattered jeans and free-style
hair, puffing on a joint, will find that the admiration his
care-free actions generate on campus is not to be found
in the Real World. There is no more tragic sight than the
Big Man On Campus who one apring struts across his
turf like a sexual tycoon, while the next finds him
cowering in some executive's office with a fresh haircut,
groveling for a job.

Post-Graduate Depression is usually over when the
subject has adapted to the Real World, i.e. is self-supporting, and has adjusted his/her social life to the
working routine. The transformation is tough, because
the job market is crowded. And if you're a white male,
your shot at a good management track program is cut
by, say, 2/3, because those women who were once
content to be secretaries, and those minorities who once
never made it to college, want a slice of your action with a vengeance. That realization doesn't make your
ego feel any better when the days are long and lean.
Adjusting socially is as tough as getting the job.
First, you can't party until four in the morning and then
sleep through that ten o'clock class. Chronic absenteeism can blight your budding career pronto. Not only
that, but after you graduate, you find you can't hang
out in front of Levering, or in the Rat, Library, coffee
shop, or other former favorite haunts, without attracting
the goading question, "What are you doing here?" I
swear that I have encountered this question almost every
time I've been on campus since that September in '78
when I glumly closed my Gilman bank account(low on
funds) as the cheery underclassmen returned. The
question is irritating in any case, because it implies
(correctly) that you're no longer "one of us." And if
you have a lousy job or no job, you don't want to field
the inevitable questions about what you're doing with
your life, especially if those questions are tossed at you
by some bright-eyes undergrad who wields the whip
innocently but effectively. I mean, you already have
your dad telling you to "get a job" and asking "Why do
you think I spent a fortune putting you through
school?"
See what I mean? When you graduate, you have
a new social status and role as surely as a man in nineteenth century America who is suddenly transmogrified
from white to black. And the people who aren't standing in your shoes will not give a shit about your predicament. Those who haven't gotten this far don't know
what you're going through, and those who have already
passed this stage don't want much to do with anyone
who is going through "that stage." Those who have
successfully resisted the urge to become a leftist during
school sometimes succumb in the midst of Post-Graduate Depression. They thus suddenly stumble onto a
dandy new make-shift philosophy -"Hey, everybody
ought to have a job!" This usually lasts until capitalism
has mercy on them and gives them a place in the sun,at
which point they abandon their foolish ideas and completely forget about everyone back in the ringer.

I was one, there aren't a lot of alternatives. The fact
that one was, say, the smartest kid in one's High School
